data.title: List of Alternate Monarchs and Aristocratic Lineage II
data.meta_description:
Joseph I (Bonaparte), King of Naples (b. 1768) married Marie Julie Clary (b. 1771) in 1794

Julie Joséphine (b. 1796) married Ferdinand VII, King of Spain...
data.text:
Henry VIII of England (1491-1524) married a) Catherine of Aragon (1485-1516) and b) Eleanor of Austria (1498-1558) with issues

1)Elizabeth (1510-1536) married Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor (1500-1558) with issues ​

​

1) Catherine (1527-1609) married Maximilian II, Holy Roman Emperor and King of Bohemia and Hungary (1527-1576) with issues ​

​

2) Philip II of Spain (1528-1600) married Caterina of Portugal (1528-1602) with issues ​

​

3) Isabella (1530-1615) married John IV of Portugal (1530-1601) with issues ​

​

4) John, Duke of Burgundy (1533-1600) married Joan de Valois (1535-1600) with issues ​

​

5) Ferdinand, Duke of Milan (1536-1594) married Lucrezia d'Este (1535-1609) with issues ​

​

​

​

​

​

2) Catherine (1511-1581) married John III, King of Portugal (1502-1557) as second wife with issues ​

​

1)Caterina (1528-1602) married Philip II of Spain (1528-1600) with issues ​

​

2)John IV of Portugal (1530-1601) married Isabella of Spain (1530-1615) with issues ​

​

3)Ferdinand, Duke of Guarda (1532-1587) married Luisa, Duchess of Guarda (1534-1600) with issues ​

​

4) Maria Isabella (1538-1609) married Henry IX, King of England (1538-1600) with issues ​

​

​

​

3)Joan (1513-1547) married Francis I of France (1494-1547) as his second wife with issues ​

​

1)John IV of Navarre, Duke of Berry (1530-1575) married Joan III, Queen of Navarre (1528-1579) with issues ​

​

2) Louise (1532-1600) married Sigiumund II Augustus, King of Poland and Grand Duke of Lithuania (1520-1579) with issues ​

​

3) Joan (1535-1600) married John of Austria, Duke of Burgundy (1533-1594) with issues ​

​

4) Philip, Duke of Alençon (1537-1579) married Henriette of Cleves, Duchess of Nevers and Countess of Rethel (1542-1601) with issues ​

I'm not sure if anything will come of it but I have been tossing around a new TL idea in my head

Henry VII of England m. Elizabeth of York and had issue.

1. Arthur I of England (b. 1486)

m. Catherine of Aragon (b.1485)

- had issue

2. Margaret (b. 1489)

m. James, King of Scotland

- had issue

3. Henry, Duke of York (b. 1491)

4. Elizabeth (b. 1492)

5. Mary (b. 1498)

6. Edmund, Duke of Somerset (b. 1499)

7. Katherine (b.1503)

Hail Mary pass for all of the Tudor kids here and I've always wanted to play with an Arthur/Catherine pairing so here we are, I was considering a Mary and Charles V's betrothal doesn't fall through here but I'm still working out ideas/details for matches.

Hail Mary pass for all of the Tudor kids here and I've always wanted to play with an Arthur/Catherine pairing so here we are, I was considering a Mary and Charles V's betrothal doesn't fall through here but I'm still working out ideas/details for matches.

If you have Katherine Tudor still born and living she will be the one engaged to Charles V NOT Mary (who was born in 1496 not 1498 by the way)

Henry VIII m. Catherine of Aragon (a) Anne Boleyn (b) Jane Seymour (c)

1a. Stillborn daughter

2a. Henry, Duke of Cornwall

3a. Stillborn son

4a. Miscarriage

5a. Mary I Queen of England, Duchess of Palatinate-Neuburg & Württemberg m. Philippe I, Duke of Palatinate-Neuburg & Württemberg, King-consort of England (1)

A. Catherine of Wittelsbach m. Louis, Duke of Orléans

B. Henry I, Duke of Palatinate-Neuburg & Württemberg, Elector Palatine (died unmarried)

C. Philippe II, Duke of Palatinate-Neuburg & Württemberg, Elector Palatine m. Margaret of Austria

D. Louis II of England m. Mary I of Scotland (a) Mary of Northumberland (b)

E. Mary of Wittelsbach m. Charles II, Archduke of Austria

6a. Miscarriage

7a. Stillborn

1b. Elisabeth of England, Duchess of Northumberland m. Robert I Duke of Northumberland

A. Elisabeth of Northumberland m. Charles II, Duke of Bourbon

B. Robert II, Duke of Northumberland m. Lady Katherine Grey

C. Mary of Northumberland m. Louis II of England

2b. Stillborn

3b. Miscarriage

1c. Edward VI of England

1. He is given the Duchy of Wüttemberg as reward for his services to the Emperor

A small one today, but a new favourite crackship of mine Let's call it "The Queen and The King"

Margrethe II, Queen of Denmark (b. 1940) m. Elvis Presley (1935-2017) in 1966 – Had Issue

1. Frederik Elvis Vernon Christian (b. 1968)

2. Louise Margrethe Gladys Ingrid (b. 1970)

3. Charlotte Alexandrine Magnolie Dagmar (b. 1972)

Now, the thing is that this ship actually could have been somewhat feasible. Queen Margrethe actually met Elvis in 1960, but the musically and culturally inclined princess did not care much for his music. I've added a pic of their meeting below (Margrethe is the women on the left!)

@FalconHonour @TheBeanieBaron @Awkwardvulture @Tudorfan @Victoria @Dragonboy @VVD0D95 @The_Most_Happy @RedKing @Kellan Sullivan

Well this takes the saying Elvis is King to a whole new meaning.

A Different Fate for Denmark in the 19th Century?

Frederik VI, King of Denmark [1814-1839], King of Denmark & Norway [1808-1814] (1768-1839) m: 1790 Marie of Hesse-Kassel (b.1767)

​

Christian (1791-1791)​

​

Maria Louisa (1792-1793)​

​

Caroline, Kronprinsesse of Denmark (b.1793) m: 1813 Christian[1], Prince of Hesse-Kassel (1776-1818[2])​

​

Karl Ludwig, Prince of Hesse-Kassel (b.1814) m: 1837 Therese of Nassau[3] (b.1815)​

​

Friedrich (b.1816)​

​

Louisa (1795-1795)​

​

Christian (1797-1797)​

​

Juliane Louisa (1802-1802)​

​

Frederikke Marie (1805-1805)​

​

Vilhelmina Marie (b.1808) m: ?​

[1] Son of Prince Karl of Hesse and Lovisa of Denmark

[2] He lives a bit longer than OTL, but still predeceases his father

[3] Daughter of Wilhelm of Nassau and Luise of Saxe-Hildburghausen. I figure he’d marry as a “minor” prince of Hesse rather than a Danish prince (despite the fact that he’s likely raised in Denmark his whole life)

So my question is this: how does Caroline having two boys affect things? Does the crown pass to Christian VIII (like OTL) or does Frederik VI fiddle with the succession laws to allow his grandson to succeed him? Or does it go Christian VIII, Frederik VII (as OTL), then jump to Karl Ludwig (instead of the Glucksburgs as OTL)

@King of Danes @Jürgen @Zulfurium

So my question is this: how does Caroline having two boys affect things? Does the crown pass to Christian VIII (like OTL) or does Frederik VI fiddle with the succession laws to allow his grandson to succeed him? Or does it go Christian VIII, Frederik VII (as OTL), then jump to Karl Ludwig (instead of the Glucksburgs as OTL)

F6 really wasn’t happy with Christian Frederick after his stunt in Norway. With a grandson, he may well disinherit him. I’d imagine Caroline’s son have Christian as one of his names just to make it go down smoother.

F6 really wasn’t happy with Christian Frederick after his stunt in Norway. With a grandson, he may well disinherit him. I’d imagine Caroline’s son have Christian as one of his names just to make it go down smoother.

So my question is this: how does Caroline having two boys affect things? Does the crown pass to Christian VIII (like OTL) or does Frederik VI fiddle with the succession laws to allow his grandson to succeed him? Or does it go Christian VIII, Frederik VII (as OTL), then jump to Karl Ludwig (instead of the Glucksburgs as OTL)

Gods, I really am unsure here. I think that the throne would still go to C8 and F7 here due to them being so closely related and mainline Oldenburgs but afterwards I could imagine it going to Karl Ludwig. Despite not being an Oldenburg (or a cadet branch like the Glucksburgs), he is raised in Denmark and is the old king’s grandson. However, Frederick William II of Hesse-Kassel was in a similar situation otl (a nephew of Christian VIII and born in Denmark) and he was still displaced by his sister and Christian IX

F6 really wasn’t happy with Christian Frederick after his stunt in Norway. With a grandson, he may well disinherit him. I’d imagine Caroline’s son have Christian as one of his names just to make it go down smoother.

I was trying to avoid him having Christian or Frederik among his names, mostly because we narrowly missed out on having "King Ferdinand" of Denmark round the same time

Gods, I really am unsure here. I think that the throne would still go to C8 and F7 here due to them being so closely related and mainline Oldenburgs but afterwards I could imagine it going to Karl Ludwig. Despite not being an Oldenburg (or a cadet branch like the Glucksburgs), he is raised in Denmark and is the old king’s grandson. However, Frederick William II of Hesse-Kassel was in a similar situation otl (a nephew of Christian VIII and born in Denmark) and he was still displaced by his sister and Christian IX

I always understood it that it was only because his sister was married to Christian IX that he was "passed over" in the succession?

I was trying to avoid him having Christian or Frederik among his names, mostly because we narrowly missed out on having "King Ferdinand" of Denmark round the same time

I mean even the Hereditary Prince Ferdinand was named Frederick Ferdinand, and may well have used the former as his regnal name. But of course, there’s no natural law that says that Christian and Frederick are the only two options.

I always understood it that it was only because his sister was married to Christian IX that he was "passed over" in the succession?

More than anything it was because he was the preferred candidate of Emperor Nicholas I.
